thread.title: Did you see the Northern Lights? Aurora borealis brightens N.J. night sky.
thread.title_full: Did you see the Northern Lights? Aurora borealis brightens N.J. night sky.

author: Chris Sheldon
title: Did you see the Northern Lights? Aurora borealis brightens N.J. night sky.
text:
Updated: Oct. 10, 2024, 10:45 p.m. | Published: Oct. 10, 2024, 8:45 p.m.
Bright purple lights glowed in the sky over Wantage in Sussex County Thursday night, thanks to a large solar flare that caused the Northern Lights to be seen in New Jersey and many other states that don't see the atmospheric phenomenon too often. Rob & Antoinette Janmaat
By Chris Sheldon | NJ Advance Media for NJ.com The aurora borealis, or Northern Lights, could be seen in the sky across New Jersey Thursday night and many residents were able to capture photos of the rare atmospheric phenomenon.
The spectacular sight made the sky above the Garden State glow with a purple and pink-colored light, which drew residents out to snap some pictures, including the National Weather Service in Mount Holly.
ðŸ¤© Here is our view of the aurora borealis (northern lights from our office around 7:15 PM! What are you seeing at your location? pic.twitter.com/F4DiNKaDsQ
â€” NWS Mount Holly (@NWS_MountHolly) October 10, 2024 Photos were blasted all over social media from as far north as Wantage in Sussex County to as far south as Bayville in Ocean County.
The sky was glowing in multiple colors late Thursday night in Wantage in Sussex County as the Northern Lights returned to the atmosphere following a large solar storm. Rob & Antoinette Janmaat
The aurora borealis as seen from Bayville in Ocean County Submitted Photo
The Northern Lights are courtesy of a severe geomagnetic storm caused by a large solar flare.
Geomagnetic storms are natural events triggered by explosions on the sun, which spark bright colors glowing in the sky .
The Northern Lights seen in Edison on Thursday, Oct. 10, 2024. Len Melisurgo
Weather experts said the storm could be strong enough to disrupt some communications satellites and parts of the power grid, but it was unclear if there were any incidents like that Thursday night.
The National Weather Service said the peak period of the Northern Lights was expected to be between 7:45 p.m. Thursday and 2 a.m. Friday.
The aurora borealis as seen from Haddon Heights in Camden County. Photo Courtesy of Pamela Pollard

Reporter Len Melisurgo contributed to this report.
